CLIST.TITLE: sites testing latency, speed, and other stuff

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all: the new Tomcat features.

X.ST: Naming and the problem of persistence

ARTICLE.COMMENT: What are the differences between a URI, a URL and a URN? The answer provided here is not so clear.

X.ST: Learn about the concepts, benefits, and industry compliance of this next-generation protocol

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short description of the IPv6 address syntax and a list of products supporting IPv6.

X.ST: Design Patterns and Business Models for the Next Generation of Software

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The new trends of the Internet, which are refered as Web2.0: the Web is the plateform, using the users to build value, the data is the value, continuous software upgrade, lightweight programming models, target any device (non only the PC) and rich GUIs.

X.T: Technologies to Watch: A Look at Four That May Challenge Java’s Development Dominance

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some new technologies (dynamic languages, frameworks supporting continuation, data links defined by convention instead of configuration and metaprogramming) may displace Java from the leader place in Web programming. But it is difficult to find the future next hip technology…
A description of Equinix data warehouse.
A description of the evolution of Web applications, there is nothing new in this article.

X.T: Kevin Kelly: The next 5,000 days of the web
Kevin Kelly: The next 5,000 days of the web

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Kevin Kelly describes his vision of Internet future: this one is very similar to common ideas about the subject (everything will be connected to the Internet, the semantic Web…).
This talk about delivering the "right information to the right people in the right time" is much too abstract, there is no valuable information here.

X.T: Supporting Casual Data-Centric Interactions on the Web

ARTICLE.COMMENT: David Huynh presents several of his projects aimed at enabling non programmers to publish and to retrieve structured data from the Web: Exhibit, Piggy Bank, Sifter, Potluck…

X.T: HOP: A Language for Programming the Web 2.0

ARTICLE.COMMENT:
Yet another language to write applications running across the Web (computer, phone, HIFI…). The slides are unreadable, but they are accessible at http://hop.inria.fr/talks/hopdiffuse.xhtml.gzhttp://hop.inria.fr/talks/hopdiffuse.xhtml.gz
enHTML.

X.T: Google Earth, Nine Inch Nails, and Real-time Geo Community

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A technical presentation of a iPhone application handling geolocated messages of NIN fans.
Joel Spolsky is presenting his site: available features, used technologies, user base growth…

X.T: URL shortening is hot--but look before you leap
X.ST: Fueled by Twitter's popularity, services to abbreviate Web addresses are taking off. They bring a host of problems, but some are working to fix them.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: With Twitter popularity, more and more URL shortener sites are created. URL shortening has some interesting side effects and also some drawbacks.
Marc Canter presents his idea of a tool, using an outline representation, to manage data across several sites.

X.T: Whats eating Scientific Data? 21st Century Approaches to Discovering (Chemical) Data

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The application of some semantic Web technologies to chemistry.

X.T: Beyond Web 2.0 -- How RDFa Can Help to Democratise Data on the Web

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some use examples of RDFa: vertical search engines, richer customisable UI…

X.T: Video: Delete Flash cookies to protect online privacy

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to manage Flash cookies using the Adobe Flash Player Settings Manager.
After a presentation of the economics of the Web, Daniel A. Nagy presents a prototype he created: a Firefox extension managing micropayments.

X.T: An overview of the Chrome Web Store Licensing API

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.ST: Why we need HTML5 video and how to use it

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A history of the video on the Web and the current status with HTML 5 and its different formats and codecs.

X.T: Look ahead to emerging web technologies in 2011
X.ST: 20 years after its inception, the web is still developing

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A prediction of 2011 trends: cloud computing, two-ways communication between the server and the Browser, cross-platform development tool, CoffeeScript, geolocalisation, data synchronization across devices, and user interface.

X.T: YUI Theater — Allen Rabinovich: "The Many Hats of the Frontend Engineers" (37 min.)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Allen suggests that a front-engineer should be at the same time an engineer, an anthropologist, a writer, an artist, a paranoid, and a futurist.

X.T: To Harness The Long Tail Online, Location Does Matter As Does Time

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some statistical analysis (whose curves seem to me to be too beautiful to be true) shows that the repartition of visited sites depends on the location and on the week day. The presenter claims that this can be used to model the long tail, but his studies seem to be far from reaching this goal.

X.T: Move Over Google Analytics, Here Comes Woopra!

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author advises to use Woopra because of its real time reporting.

X.T: Scott Schiller: Web Audio - HTML5 + Flash (in a tree)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The current status of the Browser audio support, the SoundManager library and some demos.
A presentation of the intends of the Independent Web and some of the technologies it uses.

X.T: Prototype web applications with CouchDB and Bootstrap
X.ST: Separate web design from database design, then glue them back together

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A very unclear description of building an application with CouchDB, Apache, jQuery and Bootstrap.

X.T: Verify and convert JSON payloads dynamically for cloud-based applications

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of JVAX (JSON Verification and Conversion/Transformation), a JSON validator using schemas.

X.T: Does The Browser Have A Future - Tim Bray

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The current status of Web technologies and the future of the Browser.

X.T: Using Dojo to extend business processes to the mobile space
X.ST: Dojo and WebSphere Application Server Feature Pack for Web 2.0 and Mobile provide function and flexibility

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using IBM Process Design, IBM Process Server and Dojo to model and implement a business process.

X.T: Chinese Standard Web Fonts: A Guide to CSS Font Family Declarations for Web Design in Simplified Chinese

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some advice on setting up a Chinese font.

X.T: New Research: The Ad Injection Economy

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some information about ad injecting malware.
Some advice on getting popular posts: do the easy stuff to engage readers, but no more; define a minimum level of post quality; publish everything that is above this minimum quality level.

X.T: An intro to progressive web apps

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: Reactive Web Design: The secret to building web apps that feel amazing

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Tyring to create a new buzzword "Reactive Web Design" which is skeleton screen + stable load (i.e. avoiding parts of the page jumping around during the page load).

X.ST: How I approach and create a small brand from scratch in a day.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author explains how she designs a simple brand : logo, fonts…
A non technical history of Web fonts.

X.T: Beyond SPAs: alternative architectures for your PWA

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A detailed example of building a Web app using Babel, Rollup, Express and Workbox.
A short description of the application shell architecture.
An overview of the rendering options: from static server-side rendering to full client-side rendering.

X.T: Using bluemail to renew the design and study of enterprise email

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Bluemail is an email client supporting folders, tags, threads and "orienteering." The IBM team analyzed the use of this prototype: threads are used, tags are not, some people classify all they mails while others classify nothing…

X.T: Why Am I Getting All This Spam? Unsolicited Commercial E-mail Research Six Month Report

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A study of where spammers are harvesting email addresses.

X.T: Spam, Phishing, and Online Scams: A View from the Network-Level

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Trying to detect spam by analysing the sender behaviour on the network rather that the content of the mails.

X.T: Numbers, Numbers -- But What Do They Mean?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Danny describes the meaning of the two sizes publicized by search engines. This is a good introduction on the algorithms used by Inktomi, FAST, Google, Excite…
Using Google to track the popularity of XML schemas.

X.T: Votre site est en sandbox ? C'est la faute à Wikipedia !

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A bad side effect of having your site referred in Wikipedia: spam sites copies Wikipedia pages and so Google believes your site is also a spam site.

X.T: Top 10 SEO Improvements You Can Make Right Away
X.ST: We present the top ways to quickly make gains in search engine optimization.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: 4 Reasons Why SEM Is Better Than SEO
X.ST: Is SEO relevant for next-gen marketing? Consider the alternative.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: Lords of the Links: Go Guides

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The volunteer Internet directories (Go Guides, Open Directory) are becoming a real mess.

X.T: Will Open Source Lose the Battle for the Web?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Ganesh thinks that Apache does not fulfill anymore the Web needs: services support is required. He proposes to go Java and J2EE.
How to use Apache to provide the expiration date in the HTTP headers.
How to be able to count ads hit while keeping them cached.

X.T: Twitter WTF? - Why is Twitter Called a Threat to Google?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: I do not find anything interesting in this presentation, but this is probably because I still do not understand the value of Twitter compared to what is already present on the Web (RSS, IM…).

X.T: A quick Twitter guide and glossary for business users

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good introduction to using Twitter.

X.T: How to conduct a Web site competitive analysis

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A basic plan to perform and report Web site comparison.

X.ST: Common usability problems and solutions

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some advice on using the form components: text fields, buttons, dropdowns…

X.ST: Client-side scripts for improved usability

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The pros and cons of using scripting (JavaScript, Flash…).

X.T: Start Here to learn about Web services
X.ST: Get a grounding on the basic concepts

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A very high level overview of Web services with pointers toward articles presenting the technologies.

X.T: Overview of Some Patterns for Architecting and Managing Composite Web Services

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An overview of Web services architecture and issues. I know that the design pattern fashion is still much hyped but what is the point to call this "proto-patterns"?

X.ST: Syndication goes mainstream

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good overview (schema, readers, feeds, search engines…) of the current state of RSS.

X.T: Top 5 Mistakes in Designing an ASP.NET Web Form

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some suggestions on designing forms. They are more the personal opinion of the author, some of these ideas would not be agreed by anyone.
A review of TopStyle 5, a HTML5 & CSS3 editor for Windows.

X.T: Which Open Source Wiki Works For You?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An overview of some Wiki implementations, the list is long, but the analysis of each Wiki is very limited.
I though that Wikis can be a good way to organize project documentation, this article convinces me that the technology is not mature enough! I have no time for such hacked customization.

X.T: XWiki: the french open source cousin of JotSpot

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A demo of XWiki.
Some technical and functional information about MediaWiki current status and future improvements.
A description of some new features (including the new editor), the infrastructure, and some Google Summer of Code projects.

X.T: Dat + Federated Wiki Mozilla Science Lab Global Sprint 2015 Demo

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A demo of a data pipeline in Federated Wiki.

X.T: Seero: Mapping live video to create a unique form of content.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A start-up proposing a solution for geo-tagged live/archived videos.

X.ST: Create a KML service from ESRI shapefile data

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Getting data from United States Census Bureau's TIGER and using PostGIS to create a KML document.

X.T: Blaise Aguera y Arcas demos augmented-reality maps

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A demo of Bing Maps with video registration and Worldwide Telescope integration.

X.T: Eric Gelinas: Geo Interfaces for Actual Humans

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some advice on using maps and a short presentation of the available map services, with the particular example of Flickr.
An introduction to REST, a comparison with SOAP, and why REST should be used rather than SOAP.
A short introduction explaining REST and its benefits.

X.T: REST in Practice, in Practice - Ian Robinson

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Description of a REST API to access a graph database and another API (HTML API) when this is more adequate.
A presentation of CouchDB, a database engine supporting offline replication This talk is too much verbose and not enough technical.

X.T: JavaScriptDB: Persevere’s New High-Performance Storage Engine

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of Perservere, a JSON storage and JavaScript application server.
The lead developer of Plurk explains why he likes Redis, an in-memory databse.

X.T: High Performance Web Sites and YSlow

ARTICLE.COMMENT:
Souders describes the importance of the front-end in the performance, the fact that data is most often not cached… Then, he details some of his 14 rules:
Make fewer HTTP requets
Use a CDN
Add an Expires header
Gzip components
Put stylesheets at the top
Move scripts at the bottom
Make JS and CSS external
Minify JS
Avoid redirects
Make AJAX cacheableAt last, he speaks about his tool to check if these rules are respected: YSlow.

X.T: Life's Too Short - Write Fast Code (part 2)

ARTICLE.COMMENT:
Some new rules
Load scripts without blocking
Couple asynchronous scripts
Flush the document early
Use iframes sparinglySouders focuses on the two first bullets, describing several solutions with their pros & cons, since none of them is the best for all situations.

X.T: YDN Theater — Julien Lecomte: "High Performance Ajax Applications"

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some advice on how to write fast AJAX.

X.T: Faster HTML and CSS: Layout Engine Internals for Web Developers

ARTICLE.COMMENT: David Baron explains some internals of Firefox that should be taken into account to improve page and script performance.
The advices given by Douglas Crockford are basic performance good practices, but his description of applying these to Ajax is clear and effective.

X.T: YUI Theater — Nicole Sullivan: "Design Fast Websites (Don't Blame the Rounded Corners)"

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to design a fast site: create a component library, avoid using too many styles, crush images, avoid non-standard browser fonts…
Several workarounds to avoid the fact that Browsers download, parse and execute each script before downloading the other components.

X.T: Episodes: a Framework for Measuring Web Page Load Times

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of Episodes.
A description of how Flickr implemented a very fast auto-completion for the contact list.

X.T: Not Just a Pretty Face: Performance and the New Yahoo! Search

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of the implementation of the new Yahoo results page.

X.T: Analyzing Bandwidth and Latency on YUIBlog.com

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some statistics on the latency and the bandwidth of YUIBlog readers.

A presentation of some well known performance subjects:
- How to limit the slowness of interacting with the DOM
- How to have a responsive interface
- Multipart XHR (transferring many resources – CSS, images… – in a single HTTP request)
- Combining, minifying, compressing, proper management of the Browser cache, using a CDN
- Network analyzers and profilers.

X.T: Top 10 Performance Problems taken from Zappos, Monster, Thomson and Co

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A quick description, with some pointers toward more information, of some common Web server performance issues.

X.T: Google I/O 2010 - Measure in milliseconds: Meet Speed Tracer

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of Google's JavaScript profiler.

X.T: Top 10 Client-Side Performance Problems in Web 2.0

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The same for the Ajax clients.

X.ST: Measure performance with Firebug, Safari Web Inspector, YUI Profiler, and YSlow

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some Ajax performance advice and a list of tools to analyze performance. This information is basic and already known, but this is a good overview for someone new in this domain.

X.T: How Edmunds Decreased Page Load Time by 80% in 3 Simple Steps

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to handle the ads so the site gets faster.
Using Ant to automate the minification, file concatenation, file versioning…

X.T: Santa Tracker - 1.6 Million Requests per Second

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of the technical design implemented to support such a load.

X.T: 50 performance tricks to make your HTML5 apps and sites faster

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

window.onload() is commonly used to measure performance. But given today's page structure (e.g. delayed loadings via AJAX), this measure is wrong. A new one is required, but there is still no clear solution.

An explanation of the waterfall created by WebPagetest.orghttp://www.webpagetest.org
enHTML and how to detect some common performance problems by using it.
The two guys analyze some sites and explain how to find the performance bottlenecks and solve them.

X.ST: what every web developer should know about networking and browser performance

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some general ideas about performance: latency, HTTP2.0, W3C navigation timing, battery life, WiFi…
A good and short explanation on how to properly exploit the Browser cache.

X.T: Speed is now a landing page factor for Google Search and Ads

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Page speed is now a ranking factor for mobile searches, so this blog points toward PageSpeed Insights and Lighthouse.

X.T: Web Performance Made Easy: Google I/O 2018 edition

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good overview on how to improve the performance of a site.
Some miscellaneous ideas on network performance.
An experiment trying to measure DNS performance.

X.T: Image Optimization Part 1: The Importance of Images

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Images represent a very large part of a page weight.

X.T: Image Optimization Part 2: Selecting the Right File Format

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short description of the images formats and their supports by the Browsers.

X.T: Image Optimization, Part 3: Four Steps to File Size Reduction

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some tools to reduce image size with no quality loss.

X.T: Image Optimization, Part 4: Progressive JPEG...Hot or Not?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An analysis to determine when progressive JPEG gives files smaller than normal JPEG.
Avoid using AlphaImageLoader CSS filter: it freezes the rendering and it uses too much memory.

X.T: Performance on Yahoo! Search for Earth Day

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author explains how he optimized a simple page.
Some new rules have been added: JavaScript boot-up time, inefficient cache policy and avoiding page redirects.
New SEO rules, manual accessibility audits and image format verification.
New performance and SEO rules, updated Accessibility scoring, slight UI changes.
The title says all.

X.T: Using Lighthouse To Improve Page Load Performance

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A slight display change and new rules.
Platform Packs is a mechanism to extend Lighthouse with platform specific recommendations.

X.T: Nighttime Story: Learning From Early Success of One Thousand and One Rails Ap...

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A small part of this talk is about Ruby and DTrace, but the most important and most interesting portion is about creating scalable Web applications in general.

X.T: Handicapping cloud computing: The big picture

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A Bernstein Report analyses the current market of cloud providers and concludes that cloud computing will not dominate the software landscape.

X.T: Cloud Services: Making Sense of IaaS, PaaS, and SaaS

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: Create Linux and Windows images for OpenStack private clouds
X.ST: A new method for OpenStack image construction

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The authors propose a worklflow to automate image creation.

X.T: Creating Applications with Amazon EC2 and S3

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A step by step description of using Amazon's EC2.

X.T: Cloud computing with Amazon Web Services, Part 1: Introduction
X.ST: When it's smarter to rent than to buy

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good high level presentation of Amazon Web Services: Simple Storage Service (S3), Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2), Simple Queue Service (SQS), and SimpleDB (SDB).

X.T: Cloud computing with Amazon Web Services, Part 2: Storage in the cloud with Amazon Simple Storage Service (S3)-- Reliable, flexible, and inexpensive storage and retrieval of your data

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good overview of S3: feature, price, and snippets for using the Java library.

X.T: Cloud computing with Amazon Web Services, Part 3: Servers on demand with EC2

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Features, price, and some Ruby snippets (right_aws) for EC2.

X.T: Cloud computing with Amazon Web Services, Part 4: Reliable messaging with SQS

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good introduction as usual, this time with boto, a python library.

X.T: Cloud computing with Amazon Web Services, Part 5: Dataset processing in the cloud with SimpleDB

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of SDB, also done by using boto.

X.T: The Story of Apollo - Amazon’s Deployment Engine

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some little information on Amazon's continuous deployment system and the fact that AWS users can also have a CD mechanism with CodeDeploy.

X.T: Developing and deploying an application on Google App Engine

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some evangelism for Google App Engine: a demo of writing a very simple application.
Some basic advice on using Python and Java App Engine.

X.T: Getting Started with the Google Data Python Client Library

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A very basic introduction to the Google Python API.

X.T: Google I/O 2009 - Google Wave: Under the hood

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of some details of Wave design (algorithm, data encoding…).

X.T: Google I/O 2009 - Programming With and For Google Wave

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Embedding Wave, writing gadgets and robots.

X.T: Google Wave: Powered by Google Web Toolkit

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of some technologies used to implement and test Wave: GWT (and the improvements done on it while Wave was being created), Web Driver…

X.T: DOs and DON'Ts of Mobile Strategy

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some interesting food for thought for companies looking to support mobile access to their Web site.

X.T: Stephen Woods: Creating Responsive HTML5 Touch Interfaces

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some advice for implementing a responsive UI on a touch screen of a mobile.
The two LinkedIn engineers give their feedback on creating the mobile version on LinkedIn: local storage, memory leaks, unloading images…

Porting applications to a mobile is not simply adapting the layout to smaller screens, but taking into account that mobile devices are another media. Luke Wroblewski takes the examples of the login and the checkout pages.
A little about technology, some numbers, the current state of SPDY usage… This talk is not a very good presentation of SPDY.
